docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton used a town hall forum in Rochester yesterday in part to answer what she acknowledged were continuing concerns about her ambitions and motives in running for a Senate seat representing a state where she had never lived until five months ago. Would she serve a full six-year term?

docs.lead_paragraph: Fashion Meets Politics Early on in the Clinton presidency, Ellen Mullman, a sales executive for Tamotsu, a Japanese designer based in New York, received a call from the White House. Ms. Mullman did not make the immediate association most people do when they hear the words ''White'' and ''House'' in conjunction, which is to say, she did not call to mind the residential complex that is host to the nation's highest profile Easter egg hunt. Instead, Ms. Mullman said, she thought to herself, ''That's a dumb name for a store.'' The White House -- the one in which no clothes are sold -- was calling because Hillary Rodham Clinton wanted to buy some Tamotsu pants and skirts. ''We're an unknown name, we're not a Calvin Klein name,'' Ms. Mullman said. One of Mrs. Clinton's secretaries got on the phone with Ms. Mullman and asked her to send some of the conservative separates the designer is known for to Washington, in size 8. ''I was thinking, 'Liar,' '' Ms. Mullman recalled, when she heard the first lady's size. Ms. Mullman sent down some 10's and ''they all came back pinned,'' she said. ''She's truly an 8.''
docs.abstract: Front Row column on Hillary Rodham Clinton becoming customer of Tamotsu, a Japanese designer based in New York (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from Hillary Rodham Clinton's interview on Thursday with The New York Times: THE REASONS TO RUN Why the Senate? And why here? I'm running for the Senate because of the issues that I think are most important to the future of New York and America. And they happen to be concerns of mine that go back more than 30 years. And I find that those concerns are the concerns of New Yorkers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether by prearrangement or on the advice of Walter Cronkite, David Letterman was extremely gentle to Hillary Rodham Clinton as she took her first steps this week into the real world of New York's brand of performance politics. Mrs. Clinton should be pleased with the good reviews she got for composure and humor. But she should also know that this was only a small step in the direction of conducting an open campaign. Now that she is a resident of the state, it is time for Mrs. Clinton to emerge fully from the White House cocoon. New York likes its politicians available -- on the phone, at the subway, in your face. The local style is to be open to questions from constituents and reporters on any and all subjects, instead of seeking out hand-picked audiences and softball questions. To be taken seriously as a candidate, Mrs. Clinton needs to show she does not have to hide behind her advance team and press spokesman.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Hillary Rodham Clinton should be pleased with good reviews she got for composure and humor on David Letterman show, but now she needs to show she does not have to hide behind her advance team and press spokesman; says she has yet to show how well she can survive as independent operator outside cosseted world of spinners and loyalists; says New York likes its politicians available and open to questions from constituents and reporters on any and all subjects

docs.lead_paragraph: Moving to ease strains with some Jewish groups, Hillary Rodham Clinton met privately with Orthodox Jewish leaders for more than an hour yesterday, where she sought to deflect criticism of her visit to Israel last month while signaling her agreement on a number of issues raised by the group, including opposition to physician-assisted suicide. ''I was able to express my deep commitment for the security and well-being of Israel,'' the Democratic candidate for United States Senate told reporters after the meeting at the downtown headquarters of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America. ''I was able to discuss the role that I believe the United States should rightly play in supporting Israel as it takes risks for peace.''
docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in meeting with Orthodox Jewish leaders, seeks to deflect criticism of her visit to Israel last month and agrees with group on number of issues (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Everybody agrees that something historically momentous has occurred in the White House. But it is not that the first lady is seeking political office on her own. It is that the first lady is moving out of the White House while her husband is still occupying it. Mrs. Clinton is packing her bags for New York and decorating the Christmas tree in Washington. As usual, a Clinton is in two places at one time. But the magnitude of this dissonance is staggering. Even as she ornaments the White House for the holidays, so as to present it to the country as a model setting for a warm family Christmas, she is taking her Oriental carpet and her easy chair and leaving the house. A carpetbagger indeed.
docs.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column on preparations by Hillary Rodham Clinton to move from White House to Chappaqua, NY, to run for US Senate seat (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a pair of trial runs at a stump speech, Hillary Rodham Clinton sounded out the themes of her expected campaign for the United States Senate today, listing the weak upstate economy, affordable health care, education, the environment, Social Security and gun control as the most important issues facing New York. So far, Mrs. Clinton has done more listening than talking on her visits to the state, often taking positions only when prodded by reporters.
docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton tests themes of her expected campaign for United States Senate, speeches, Schenectady and Albany, NY; cites range of key issues; photo (M)

headline.main: Mrs. Clinton's Listening Tour Now Evolving Into Senate Campaign

docs.lead_paragraph: In her strongest confirmation yet of what many people are already taking for granted, Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that she would almost certainly run for the United States Senate in New York next year but that she still wants the state's voters to get to know her better before she formally declares her candidacy. Asked at a news conference in lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon whether there was any possibility that she would not run for Senate, Mrs. Clinton replied, ''I think that's a remote possibility.'' Her response came after Representative Charles B. Rangel, the elder statesman of the New York Congressional delegation, said last weekend that it was time for her to make a decision.
docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton says that she will almost certainly run for US Senate from New York next year but that she wants state voters to get to know her better before she formally declares herself a candidate; photo (M)

headline.main: First Lady Steadily Inches Closer To Making Candidacy Official
